arm_group.description: no added micronutrient, tomato puree, lutein supplement, vitamin E supplement, vitamin D supplement

brief_summary.textblock:
The aim was to identify minor genetic variations (single nucleotide polymorphisms)  that
      explain the interindividual variability in bioavailability of fat soluble micronutrients
      (fat soluble vitamins and carotenoids).

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Genetic Variants on Fat-soluble Vitamin Bioavailability
clinical_study.condition: Biological Availability of Vitamins and Micronutrients

detailed_description.textblock:
Healthy male volunteers were genotyped and submitted to 5 test-meals containing either no
      micronutrient of interest, 100 g tomato puree as a source of carotenoids, a lutein
      supplement, a vitamin E supplement or a vitamin D supplement. Blood samples were taken in
      the postprandial period (up to 8 hours after the test-meals intake) and the concentration of
      the studied micronutrients were measured in the chylomicrons. Multivariate analysis were
      then performed to identify single nucleotide polymorphisms that best explained the variance
      in the interindividual response (0 to 8 h area under the curve) in micronutrients.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

        gender :  male age : 18 to 60 years old BMI: [18 to 29.9] kg/m2 Fasting Cholesterol
        concentration : < 2,5 g/l Fasting triglyceride concentration < 2 g/l Fasting glycemia ≤
        1,1 g/l Fasting Hemoglobin < 13 g/dl HIV as well as hepatitis C and B negative

        Exclusion Criteria:

        smokers regular consumption of vitamin supplement > 140 g/week alcohol vegetarian diseases
        drugs assumed to affect the metabolism of lipids or fat soluble micronutrients (e.g.
        ezetimibe)

facility.name: Centre d'Investigation Clinique de l'hôpital de la Conception

clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Genetic Variants of Intestinal Transporters of Lipophilic Micronutrients (Vitamins D, E and Carotenoids) on Absorption Efficiency of These Compounds.

oversight_info.authority: France: Afssaps - Agence française de sécurité sanitaire des produits de santé (Saint-Denis)

primary_outcome.description: The subjects were submitted to test-meals rich in micronutrients of interest and the ability of each subject to absorb the studied micronutrients was evaluated by measuring the postprandial chylomicron response (0 to 8 h area under the curve of the chylomicron micronutrient concentration) in each micronutrient.

reference.citation: Borel P. Genetic variations involved in interindividual variability in carotenoid status. Mol Nutr Food Res. 2012 Feb;56(2):228-40. doi: 10.1002/mnfr.201100322. Epub 2011 Sep 29. Review.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Institut National de la Santé Et de la Recherche Médicale, France

secondary_outcome.description: A first sample of adipose tissue was taken before the intake of the test-meal rich in fat soluble micronutrients. A second sample was taken 8 h after the test-meal intake. The aim was to assess whether the consumption of the studied fat soluble micronutrient modified the concentration of this micronutrient in adipose tissue.

clinical_study.source: Institut National de la Santé Et de la Recherche Médicale, France

collaborator.agency: Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique

lead_sponsor.agency: Institut National de la Santé Et de la Recherche Médicale, France
